definitions.definition: a place where people live temporarily in tents or temporary buildings

examples.text: to pitch/set up camp *(= put up tents)*
to break/strike camp *(= take down tents)*
We broke camp early the next morning.
We pitched camp just outside the woods.

definitions.definition: a place where children go in the summer and take part in sports and other activities

examples.text: I used to attend a summer music camp for five weeks.
He spent two weeks at camp this summer.
a **camp counsellor** *(= somebody who works with young people at a summer camp)*

definitions.definition: a place where people are kept in temporary buildings or tents, especially by a government and often for long periods

examples.text: They criticized the appalling conditions in the **refugee camps**.
They were repeatedly beaten by camp guards.

definitions.definition: a place where soldiers live while they are training or fighting
a group of people who have the same ideas about something and oppose people with other ideas

examples.text: The region split into two armed camps.
People are split into two camps on this issue.
He was a politician who switched camps when it suited him.

phrases: have a foot in both camps

definitions.definition: one of the sides in a competition and the people connected with it

examples.text: There was an air of confidence in the England camp.

phrases: have a foot in both camps

definitions.definition: to be involved in or connected with two different groups, especially ones that oppose each other

wordOrigin: noun early 16th cent.: from French camp, champ, from Italian campo, from Latin campus ‘level ground’, specifically applied to the Campus Martius in Rome, used for games, athletic practice, and military drill.
